| Coverables and coverages

¢ Acoverable is an exposure to risk and is
not explicitly defined in the product model

¢« Examples of coverables include
dwellings, autos, policy lines (named
insured)

Dwelling — a coverable

| Coverages

* Coverages are attached to coverables

* Coverages are patterns in the product ty
model where each coverage pattern is
associated with a relevant entity

¢« Examples of coverage include theft
coverage, fire coverage or liability vehicle
damage (on the policy line)

This coverable, the dwelling,
has fire coverage

| Defining coverages in the product model

¢ The product model is where you can define
coverages and coverage terms

¢ Example: an insurer may decide to add a
coverage that will insure business in the case
of cyber attacks

* Type of coverage: Liability coverage
+ What are the terms?
* Can you base this new coverage on an existing

coverage in an existing line of business (e.g.
General Liability)?

| Introducing the subclause relationship Gi

ree, Insurance companies often offer coverages as
product Manage groups or families of coverages. How can | create
subcoverages under a parent coverage in

PolicyCenter?

Marcus
Business
Analyst

This can be achieved in Advanced Product
Designer which supports the subclause
relationship for clauses (coverage,
conditions, exclusions).

| Subclause relationships in Advanced Product Designer Gi

¢ Defining subclause relationships in a mind map

« Aclause can have zero or one parent clause

« Aclause can have multiple subclauses

+ You can create multiple levels of subclauses

* The subclause and its parent must be of the same clause type
¢ Visualizing subclauses in PolicyCenter

+ Add anew or existing clause as a subclause

+ Unassign a subclause from its parent clause

+ Remove a subclause
